notes.slide-19:
Optimizations can cost code readability maintainability memory time...
so don’t optimize before there’s a real problem
Measure the optimization’s benefits so you know what you gain out of it
Measure forever because some optimizations can lose its benefits over time
Ex: browsers optimize some operations for you which can lead to better perfs than your optimizations. But if you stick to your optimizations, you’re preventing the browser from doing them, thus you lose perf! If you design an application to avoid deep prototypical inheritance because you think it’s slow, you might be disappointed when you learn that going up the prototype chain is a free operation in Chrome for instance
notes.slide-15:
S an object should have only a single responsibility
O open for extension, closed for modification (switch case example)
L an object can be replaced by an instance of its subtype
I many client specific interfaces are better than one general purpose interface ex: ATM=withdraw, deposit, account consultation...
D depend on abstraction not on concretion. Dependency injection
